#Text=Avoid Being Ripped off by a Contractor
#Text=Employing a contractor always involves a certain amount of risk .
#Text=You can significantly decrease your chances of being ripped off by by one just by taking all the steps listed below .
#Text=Just by reading number one and you could save yourself time , money and trouble .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Learn what the common scams are :
#Text=" Today Only " discounts .

column3:
abstract[20]	new[20]	_	_
7-2	347-352	Today	time|abstract[20]	new|new[20]	coref	8-13[24_0]

7-4	358-359

column1: #Text=If a contractor ever tells you the price is available for " today only " , it 's time to show him the door .
#Text=Quite often they 'll provide you a story that by signing today you 're entitled to a " model home " or " advertising discount " .

column3:

column1: #Text=The story centers around the need to use your home as a model to advertise their services in the neighborhood .
#Text=They mark their prices up just to give you this false discount .
#Text=Do n't be fooled .
#Text=This is an old trick used to pressure homeowners into making a quick decision .
#Text=This is your money we 're talking about !
#Text=Quickly ask these salespeople to leave !
#Text=Avoid contractors who ask for more than a third of the money up front .
#Text=Or even any money upfront at all ; they should n't need any kind of payments from you until the work is completed .
#Text=Avoid high pressure salespeople representing the contractor .
#Text=You should never feel pressured into making a decision about choosing your contractor .
#Text=If you ever feel that a contractor or salesman is pressuring you , ask them to back off .
#Text=If they persist , it 's time to look for another contractor .
#Text=High pressure usually leads to a bad decision when remodeling .
#Text=A qualified , reputable professional would never pressure anyone into a project .
#Text=Beware of " Door-To-Door " contractors .

column3:
object[90]|person[92]	new[90]|giv[92]	coref	25-6[94_92]
24-4	1618-1630	Door-To-Door	object[90]|organization|person[92]	new[90]|new|giv[92]	_	_
24-5	1631-1632

column1: #Text=These people may not be contractors at all .
#Text=Never allow them into your home until you have checked them out thoroughly !
#Text=This ca n't be stressed enough .

#Text=It has been recently reported that two men claiming to be contractors entered into a home , and while one took the homeowner on a pretend inspection , the other was going through purses and picking up items that could be sold quickly .
#Text=Some contractors working in your area may put out flyers or come to your door soliciting additional work in the area .
#Text=These contractors could be honest , reputable people .
#Text=But you should n't invite them in .
#Text=Instead , politely ask them for their business card and the name , address and telephone number of the people they are doing work for in the neighborhood .
#Text=Then make an appointment with that homeowner to take a look at the quality of their work .
#Text=Disputes can still arise , even when dealing with an ethical contractor .
#Text=Draw up and agree on the scope of work and produce a Bill of Quantities that clearly lists all the materials and tasks to be performed .
#Text=The Bill of Quantities should also list a Rate(cost ) per metre / m ² / m³ , etc.
#Text=That way if there are any variations or extras , you can use the rates to determine the cost of these extras .
#Text=Make use of " variation orders " or VOs , a written agreement that quantifies any changes to the originally agreed scope of work which must be signed by both parties .

column3:

column1: #Text=Make use of a construction contract - Contracts are normally available through the relevant building institutes .
#Text=These contracts normally protect the interests of both parties .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Make sure that they have licenses and insurance before any work is performed and are following city , state and federal codes to complete the work to which you have agreed on .
#Text=Always shop around between contractors when trying to find the right one for the job .
